author: By Raphael Rashid
title: A Small Group in South Korea Has a Big Homophobic Agenda
description: Radical Christians are working to erase L.G.B.T.Q. visibility from schools and ultimately, South Korean society.
content: Since South Korean voters delivered a full-throated rebuke of their conservative president this month, a small but influential group has been on edge. It fears the more liberal opposition’s landslide in the April 10 parliamentary elections could signal the country’s wrongheaded move toward what they call a homosexual dictatorship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Randy Boyagoda
title: History, Fable and the Perfect Jewish Joke Make This a Story for the Ages
description: “Lublin,” a novel by Manya Wilkinson, brings together a quest fable and a dark history with disarming humor.
content: Three Jewish village boys go to the big city to sell a box of paintbrushes. … You can’t stop me from telling this one because you haven’t heard it yet, unless you’ve already read Manya Wilkinson’s brilliant new novel, “Lublin.” With its matter-of-fact approach to depicting antisemitic violence, its three guileless main characters and its artful folding-together of fable, history and Jewish joke-making, this is a story for the moment and for the ages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judith Newman
title: These Books Might Make You Happier
description: Three new arrivals help readers make sense of our mental health crisis. They also offer solidarity.
content: With the pandemic receding and a fraught election season looming, Americans seem more concerned than ever about mental health — yours, mine and that of the next leader of the free world. According to the C.D.C., a whopping 57.2 million Americans a year make visits to the physician where the primary diagnosis turns out to be a mental disorder. That’s a whole lot of anxiety and depression.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: An Under-12 Girls’ Team Didn’t Just Beat the Boys. They Destroyed Them.
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, April 28, 2024.
content: “I just thought it was incredible that we’ve gone so far to beat some boys that are probably more physical than us. We actually came back and destroyed them.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall and Oleksandr Chubko
title: Many Ukrainian Prisoners of War Show Signs of Trauma and Sexual Violence
description: As they return with physical and psychological wounds stemming from torture by their Russian captors, soldiers are being sent back to active duty — often without adequate treatment.
content: The Ukrainian marine infantryman endured nine months of physical and psychological torture as a Russian prisoner of war, but was allotted only three months of rest and rehabilitation before being ordered back to his unit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: On This Saturday Night, Colin Jost’s Jokes Fell Flat
description: The White House Correspondents’ Association dinner has occasionally featured some great stand-up comedy. This “S.N.L.” veteran’s set will not join that list.
content: People in the media have long worried about the impact of the White House Correspondents’ Association dinner on journalism. The concern is that it makes the press look too chummy with politicians it’s covering. But what is the impact on comedy?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Trump’s Trial Could Bring a Rarity: Consequences for His Words
description: The former president has spent decades spewing thousands and thousands of words, sometimes contradicting himself. That tendency is now working against him in his Manhattan criminal case.
content: “So that’s not true? That’s not true?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: College Protests Over Gaza Deepen Democratic Rifts
description: Scenes of chaos unfolding on campuses across the country are stoking internal divisions and carry political risk as a major election year unfolds.
content: Nearly seven months after the Israel-Hamas war began, the demonstrations convulsing college campuses nationwide are exposing fresh tensions within the Democratic Party over how to balance free speech protections and support for Gazans with concerns that some Jewish Americans are raising about antisemitism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: As Colleges Weigh Crackdowns on Protests, Questions About Outsiders Linger
description: With pro-Palestinian protests spreading across campuses nationwide, university leaders have had to confront a central question: When does a demonstration cross the line?
content: Amid a dizzying array of standoffs involving pro-Palestinian demonstrations and encampments at colleges, schools that cracked down on protesters over the weekend have given varying justifications for their actions, while others sent mixed signals with their inaction.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: April 28, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, April 28, 2024.
content: An article on Page 11 this weekend about the musician Peter Gordon’s record label misidentifies the man who gave Gordon piano lessons. He was Don Agger, a journalist and brother-in-law of the Supreme Court Justice Abe Fortas, not Donald Agger, an assistant secretary in the Department of Transportation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Marche
title: Justin Trudeau Is No Match for a Polarized World
description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada and his Liberal Party are facing increasing unpopularity in an era of right-wing ascendancy.
content: Political careers often end in failure — a cliché that exists because it too often happens to be true. Justin Trudeau, one of the world’s great progressive leaders, may be heading toward that moment. In a recent interview he acknowledged that every day he considers leaving his “crazy job” as Canada’s prime minister. Increasingly, the question is not if he will leave but how soon and how deep his failure will be when he goes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner and Edward Wong
title: With Israel Poised to Invade Rafah, Negotiators Try Again for Cease-Fire Deal
description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken was headed to Saudi Arabia in search of an agreement that would pause the fighting and free hostages held by Hamas.
content: As international diplomats converged in the Middle East on Sunday seeking a cease-fire in the Gaza Strip, Israel wrestled with whether to go forward with a ground invasion of Rafah, Hamas’s last bastion in the enclave, according to Israeli officials and analysts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia and Emma Bubola
title: Asylum Seekers Already in U.K. Say Rwanda Law Creates New Anxiety
description: For the tens of thousands of asylum seekers in Britain, a new law brings the possibility of deportation to central Africa closer. We asked how it was affecting them.
content: On a cold spring day last month, Mohsen, a 36-year-old from Iran, woke before dawn and was hurried by smugglers onto a rubber boat on the coast of France.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero and Daniele Volpe
title: How Fentanyl Laid Waste to Guatemala’s Time-Worn Opium Trade
description: Reshaping the drug war in one of Central America’s most lawless corners, the fentanyl boom has devastated the trade in opium poppies used to make heroin.
content: The convoy rolled out of the military base before dawn into the mist-shrouded mountains straddling Guatemala’s border with Mexico. Its mission: destroy opium poppies used to make heroin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman and Todd Heisler
title: Homelessness Is Especially Hard on Children. Making Music Helps.
description: Therapists from the Brooklyn Conservatory of Music have found that teaching homeless children to make beats and write songs is a way to heal trauma.
content: “We’re going to be making a beat,” Dannyele Crawford said as the kids settled noisily into their seats at a homeless shelter in Brooklyn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kayla Guo
title: As He Exits Congress, Blumenauer Wants His Party to Embrace Pot Legalization
description: The long-serving congressman from Portland, who has become the top marijuana advocate on Capitol Hill, believes the issue could boost President Biden’s support with young voters.
content: As a 23-year-old serving his first term in the Oregon state legislature, Representative Earl Blumenauer cosponsored the first bill in the country to decriminalize small amounts of marijuana.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oussama Zahr
title: Review: Gustavo Dudamel Saves the Day at the Philharmonic
description: Dudamel, the New York Philharmonic’s incoming music and artistic director, stepped in after a guest conductor fell ill.
content: It was lucky that Gustavo Dudamel was in town.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review No. 1,044
description: Scroll down to reveal letters from today’s word, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Boots From Office
description: Tom Locke makes his New York Times debut.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: An Explosion in Afghanistan Nearly Killed Him. Now, It’s Inspiring His Senate Bid.
description: Sam Brown, a veteran and former Army captain, was left permanently scarred from a Taliban bomb in 2008. Can his military service drive a successful political campaign in Nevada?
content: Lying in an Afghan desert, engulfed in flames and soaked in diesel fuel, Sam Brown realized he was about to die.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Klein
title: A Close Examination of the Most Infamous Public Toilet in America
description: We think of adding regulation as something liberals do and removing regulation as something conservatives do. But that is only part of the story.
content: On a recent sunny Sunday, residents of San Francisco’s Noe Valley gathered to celebrate the opening of a toilet. But not just any toilet. This was the nation’s most infamous public toilet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azam Ahmed
title: Inside Mexico’s Brutal Drug Rehabs for the Poor
description: In a new book, an anthropologist investigates the makeshift treatment centers that have proliferated during the country’s war on drugs.
content: In “Labyrinth of Solitude,” the Nobel laureate Octavio Paz writes of his fellow Mexicans as a people so burdened by historical trauma that they are cursed to “carry about with them, in rags, a still-living past.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang
title: Tornado Kills 5 in Guangzhou, a Chinese City Battered by Recent Rains
description: Videos shared by Chinese official media showed transmission towers and power lines igniting and debris swirling in the air in the city, a manufacturing and technology hub by the Pearl River.
content: A tornado that swept through the southern Chinese economic hub of Guangzhou killed five people and damaged scores of factory buildings on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roxane Gay
title: This Ship Is Sinking. Can I Jump to a Client’s?
description: In the workplace, saving yourself is also your job.
content: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. Says Americans Are ‘Voting Out of Fear’
description: At a rally outside New York City, he questioned the nation’s Covid response and returned to a favorite issue: vaccine skepticism.
content: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. sought to make the case on Sunday that he can do something no third-party or independent candidate has come close to doing in modern U.S. history: win a presidential election. Although polls show him far behind, both major-party campaigns, those of President Biden and former President Donald J. Trump, view Mr. Kennedy as a potential spoiler.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 322
description: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Pope’s Visit to Art Exhibition in Prison Is a First for Venice Biennale
description: Incarcerated women serve as guides to the show, which reflects Pope Francis’ longtime commitment to society’s marginalized people.
content: Landing by helicopter at a women’s prison where the Vatican has mounted its pavilion for the Venice Biennale international art exhibition, Pope Francis on Sunday told the women incarcerated there that they had a “special place in my heart.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anushka Patil
title: World Central Kitchen Will Resume Operations in Gaza
description: The organization halted aid efforts in the enclave after seven of its workers were killed in an Israeli attack. It said it would resume operations with a local team of Palestinian aid workers.
content: World Central Kitchen said on Sunday that it would resume operations in Gaza with a local team of Palestinian aid workers, nearly a month after the Israeli military killed seven of the organization’s workers in targeted drone strikes on their convoy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: Louisiana Will Get a New City After a Yearslong Court Battle
description: The State Supreme Court cleared the way for a part of Baton Rouge to become the city of St. George. Critics say the white, wealthier enclave separating from the capital could have devastating consequences.
content: The original plan was to start a school district. That didn’t work. So a group of residents in a sprawling unincorporated suburb of Baton Rouge, La., expanded their idea: Create a city of their own, called St. George.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: After Period of Chastity, Hollywood Movies Embrace Sex Again
description: Studios obsessively focused on PG-13 franchises and animation in recent years, but movies like “Challengers” and “Saltburn” show eroticism has returned.
content: Zendaya, clad in a skintight dress, gyrates on a dance floor in “Challengers,” a $56 million sports drama that arrived in multiplexes on Friday. “It’s getting hot in here,” the hip-hop soundtrack intones, as she closes her eyes and runs her hands through her hair, lost in fantasy. “So take off all your clothes.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Calum Marsh
title: A New Fitness Craze With Big Drama
description: Hyrox, a sporting event founded in Germany, has earned a large following for its dazzling, high-profile races.
content: The men in the starting line at Hyrox in Berlin in April practically hummed with nervous enthusiasm. A few dozen racers, part of an early morning heat, stood watching the steady tick of a five-minute countdown, displayed on a huge television overhead. Dramatic string music played on tinny loudspeakers. A booming voice intoned a rallying cry, “This is the moment you’ve been training for!” Lights twinkled. Spectators cheered.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ted Alcorn
title: U.S. Lags Behind Other Countries in Hepatitis-C Treatment
description: Despite an arsenal of drugs, many Americans are still unaware of their infections until it’s too late. A Biden initiative languishes without Congressional approval.
content: In the 10 years since the drugmaker Gilead debuted a revolutionary treatment for hepatitis C, a wave of new therapies have been used to cure millions of people around the world of the blood-borne virus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaya Gupta
title: Robbi Mecus, Who Fostered L.G.B.T.Q. Climbing Community, Dies at 52
description: A New York State forest ranger who worked in the Adirondacks, she died after falling about 1,000 feet from a peak at Denali National Park and Preserve in Alaska.
content: Robbi Mecus, a New York State forest ranger who led search-and-rescue missions and became a prominent voice within the L.G.B.T.Q. climbing community, died on Thursday after falling about 1,000 feet from a peak at Denali National Park and Preserve in Alaska. She was 52.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Martha C. White
title: A Wealth Shift That Could Leave Some Younger Americans Behind
description: Assets held by baby boomers are changing hands, but that doesn’t mean their millennial heirs will be set for life.
content: Alainta Alcin has heard about the huge transfer of wealth from baby boomers to their millennial children that is underway — a move that has been called the largest shift of assets in history. But Ms. Alcin, an analyst for hospital systems, says it bears little resemblance to her own family’s experience.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: Colleges Have Gone off the Deep End. There Is a Way Out.
description: How do we find our way to a campus culture in which everyone can be heard?
content: I had my head in a law book when I heard the drums. That was the sound of the first campus protest I ever experienced. I’d come to Harvard Law School in the fall of 1991 as a graduate of a small, very conservative Christian college in Nashville. Many of my college classmates had passionate religious and political commitments, but street protest was utterly alien to the Christian culture of the school. We were rule followers, and public protest looked a bit too much like anarchy for our tastes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: A Taste of Now
description: Go big on asparagus while it’s in season: Slather it with miso-chile sauce, toss it in a creamy pasta with peas and mint or pair seared stalks with cashews and coconut.
content: Good morning. I love the green I’m seeing at the tips of the hardwoods, the bright harlequin vibrancy of the alliums along the stream beds, the way the grass in the park is starting to thrive again after a long winter of abuse at the feet of dogs. Here’s spring garlic at the market, funky bouquets of ramps and, best of all, asparagus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Maag
title: What’s So Funny About a Dead Comedian?
description: Kenny DeForest was beloved among his fellow stand-ups. After his sudden death, they came together to grieve — and to confront comedy’s eternal question: Too soon?
content: A few weeks after Kenny DeForest died, a group of his friends gathered in an apartment in Los Angeles. The mood was somber — Mr. DeForest was only 37, and he had died from traumatic brain injuries after falling off an electric bike in Brooklyn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: Review: A Fierce Soprano Arrives at the Met in ‘Madama Butterfly’
description: Asmik Grigorian, a star singer abroad, made her Metropolitan Opera debut by lending lyricism, complexity and spontaneity to a classic role.
content: In the most heartbreaking scene of Puccini’s opera “Madama Butterfly,” the title character waits. A teenage geisha married off to an American naval lieutenant, she remains devoted to him long after he abandons her. He will return, she believes — one fine day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: Real Estate Fantasies
description: Celebrity agents are selling a dream, as real homes get more out of reach.
content: There are few acts more optimistic than shopping for a home. You walk through its doors, run your fingertips along its appliances and see your face reflected in its windows and mirrors. You consider untapped versions of your life, imagining yourself waking up every day in that bedroom, cooking every day in that kitchen and letting the years unfold between those walls.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Maximizing Profits at the Patients’ Expense
description: Readers discuss an article about insurers sending large bills for out-of-network care. Also: Brave Trump jurors; Black voters; better than debates.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Biden Confers With Netanyahu on a Possible Cease-Fire and Hostage Deal
description: The president spoke with the Israeli prime minister on Sunday, the same day Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken left for his latest trip to the Middle East.
content: President Biden spoke with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Sunday to discuss the prospects of a possible cease-fire deal to secure the release of hostages held by Hamas, while repeating his warnings about a new Israeli assault on the city of Rafah in southern Gaza, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronen Bergman and Patrick Kingsley
title: Israeli Officials Believe International Court Is Preparing Arrest Warrants Over War
description: The officials said they thought that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and others could be charged by the International Criminal Court and that the court was also considering warrants for Hamas leaders.
content: Israeli officials increasingly believe that the International Criminal Court is preparing to issue arrest warrants for senior government officials on charges related to the conflict with Hamas, according to five Israeli and foreign officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Monday Briefing: Plans for Gaza’s Future
description: Plus, European countries crack down on China’s influence.
content: Development agencies and Middle Eastern businesses have been meeting to discuss the eventual reconstruction of Gaza and to develop plans for its long-term economic future. They seek to transform Gaza into a commercial hub centered on trade, tourism and innovation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | April 29, 2024
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
content: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Archie Cooley, Football Coach Known as ‘the Gunslinger,’ Dies at 85
description: At Mississippi Valley State University, he unleashed a high-powered, pass-heavy offense that featured the future Pro Football Hall of Famer Jerry Rice.
content: Archie Cooley, the exuberant architect of a passing-crazy offense at Mississippi Valley State University in the 1980s that featured the wide receiver Jerry Rice, a future Pro Football Hall of Famer, died on April 18 in Fort Worth. He was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nadja Spiegelman
title: The Complicated Artist Behind the Moomins
description: The Finnish artist and writer Tove Jansson had a love-hate relationship with her most famous creations.
content: Tove Jansson longed to be alone. As a child, she slept on a high shelf in her family’s home in Helsinki. Her mother, a successful illustrator, piled books from floor to ceiling and her father, a sculptor, kept a studio that dominated the majority of the space.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Nicholas Nehamas
title: Trump and DeSantis Meet for First Time Since Bruising Primary
description: The former president and his vanquished rival met in Florida, months after Ron DeSantis dropped out after a contentious Republican contest.
content: Donald J. Trump and Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida met on Sunday morning, according to three people briefed on the meeting, the first time they’ve done so since the end of a bruising Republican presidential primary that Mr. Trump won while relentlessly attacking Mr. DeSantis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter S. Goodman
title: Even With Gaza Under Siege, Some Are Imagining Its Reconstruction
description: International development agencies have been meeting with Middle East business interests and urban planners to map out an economic future for the territory.
content: On a December morning in central London, more than two dozen people drawn from influential institutions across the Middle East, Europe and the United States gathered in a conference room to pursue an aspiration that, at that moment, verged on preposterous. They were there to plan for the reconstruction and long-term economic development of Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnatan Reiss
title: In Northern Israel, Clashes With Hezbollah Drive a Hospital Underground
description: Subterranean operations at Galilee Medical Center are a striking example of how life in northern Israel has been upended since Hezbollah began launching near-daily attacks.
content: The entrance hall to the Galilee Medical Center in northern Israel is mostly empty and quiet. Roaring warplanes and the intermittent thunder of artillery have replaced the sounds of doctors, orderlies and patients at this major hospital closest to the border with Lebanon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Holland Cotter
title: On the Met Roof, Skywriting His Way to Freedom
description: Petrit Halilaj of Kosovo began drawing as a refugee child in the Balkans during a violent decade and invented a calligraphic world of memory.
content: When this old world starts getting me down
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Zucker
title: A $275 Bus Ticket to the Hamptons
description: Blade, after a decade of flying passengers to eastern Long Island on helicopters, is getting into the luxury coach business.
content: Blade, the helicopter charter company, was founded 10 years ago as a way for commuters going between New York and the Hamptons to avoid vehicle traffic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenna Russell and John Tully
title: How One Reaction to a Mural Tore a New England Town Apart
description: The 6,000 residents of Littleton, N.H., had found a way to coexist despite their differences — until a town official’s words set off a conflagration.
content: Few were present at the select board meeting in Littleton, N.H., last August when Carrie Gendreau, one of its members, began to talk about a mural that had recently been painted on the side of a building downtown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: How Real Estate Became Showbiz and Agents Became Stars
description: Fueled by the public’s love of reality TV and desire to view luxury homes, real estate agents are chasing fame as fervently as they chase deals.
content: The crowd began gathering at 5 p.m., into the movie-perfect backyard of a 1920s Spanish-style Los Angeles estate once owned by Madonna. The air was so soft and eucalyptus-scented you could wrap yourself in it. Glasses clinked. The pool glinted in the slinking sun. In the Santa Monica Mountains above, the Hollywood sign gleamed like a row of perfectly capped teeth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: ‘Guilt’ Review: When the Lights Go Out in Edinburgh
description: The final season of Scotland’s most notable TV drama, on PBS’s “Masterpiece,” is a suitably twisty and sardonic send-off for the battling McCall brothers.
content: Contains spoilers for Seasons 1 and 2 of “Guilt.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘We Locked Eyes, and Her Face Broke Into a Huge Smile’
description: Missing a morning ritual, an accidental act of recycling and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jen Silverman
title: Art Isn’t Supposed to Make You Comfortable
description: We live in a complex world. We can’t afford to make art that serves up only simple moral lessons.
content: When I was in college, I came across “The Sea and Poison,” a 1950s novel by Shusaku Endo. It tells the story of a doctor in postwar Japan who, as an intern years earlier, participated in a vivisection experiment on an American prisoner. Endo’s lens on the story is not the easiest one, ethically speaking; he doesn’t dwell on the suffering of the victim. Instead, he chooses to explore a more unsettling element: the humanity of the perpetrators.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy LaGorce
title: No Religion? At These Faith-Based Retirement Communities, No Problem.
description: Some communities with religious origins now offer spiritual programming as just one of many enticements, like the bingo nights of yesteryear.
content: Before Helen Leddy moved to Shell Point Retirement Community in Fort Myers, Fla., last year, she got the lowdown on the place from her best friend, Judy Burget.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Puerto Rico Democratic Primary Results
description: Get live election results from the 2024 Puerto Rico Democratic presidential primary.
content: Get live election results from the 2024 Puerto Rico Democratic presidential primary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Lipton, Gabriel Blanco and James Surdam
title: Kushner's Investments Could Be a Conflict of Interest for Trump
description: Jared Kushner’s Affinity Partners has invested more than $1.2 billion, much of it in firms abroad, drawing new scrutiny as his father-in-law, Donald Trump, again seeks the presidency. The New York Times Investigative Reporter, Eric Lipton, explains where the money is coming from and where it’s going.
content: Jared Kushner’s Affinity Partners has invested more than $1.2 billion, much of it in firms abroad, drawing new scrutiny as his father-in-law, Donald Trump, again seeks the presidency. The New York Times Investigative Reporter, Eric Lipton, explains where the money is coming from and where it’s going.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin and Karen Hanley
title: Our Reporter on Real Estate Reality TV
description: Fueled by the public’s love of reality TV and desire to view luxury homes, real estate agents are chasing fame as fervently as they chase deals.
content: Fueled by the public’s love of reality TV and desire to view luxury homes, real estate agents are chasing fame as fervently as they chase deals.
source.name: The New York Times
